video.title: Talking Clock - The Daily Programmer #321
video.description:
Link to the problem in the video:

topLevelComment.author: Steve K
topLevelComment.text: Do you guys plan on doing more daily programmer challenges? trying to learn javascript and this is really helpful.

topLevelComment.author: Alexandre Chetrite
topLevelComment.text: You are a very efficient and clear Javascript/Programmaing teacher! I learned more in 15 minutes with this course of yours than reading 1 houir of Javascript theory! Please do more and span all the logical algorithmic cases in Javascript!

topLevelComment.author: tony kempson
topLevelComment.text: Thanks for the video. It's a good real-world example that shows quite a lot of JavaScript techniques for noobs like myself.

topLevelComment.author: Wing N.
topLevelComment.text: thank you! as someone who has no background in coding, I have been feeling as if I have pieces to the puzzle but with not much of a clue how the big picture looks.  This video helps tie all the pieces together.

topLevelComment.author: Androzim
topLevelComment.text: Great! Thank you for time you've spent to make this video :)

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: You're welcome, glad you enjoyed it.

topLevelComment.author: LBBO
topLevelComment.text:
You missed the HH:00 case. Currently, for 00:00 your function would output "It's twelve oh am" but the description requires it to output "It's twelve am" (see 0:43 ). However, if you were to just leave the minute string empty, you would have to spaces after each other in the output string (as you did at 13:41 ). You could handle that by filtering the array for empty strings before joining them or by replaceing two spaces with one in the output string.

Otherwise, this is a nice video.

replies.author: Artur Haurylkevich
replies.text: I did a similar mistake leaving the minute string empty and get one extra space :) https://gist.github.com/dagolinuxoid/d10ad12873e09e318509b2b163474250

topLevelComment.author: paraglide01
topLevelComment.text: Hmm, that Youtube algoritme gets me everytime, from cats chasing dogs to a talking clock.....

topLevelComment.author: Lewis Cowles
topLevelComment.text: I'd have just made a massive array with the names for numbers. It's not a DB, there's no need for normalisation or processing. If you do want to avoid repeating constants, just reference unique words.

topLevelComment.author: Chriszilla1123
topLevelComment.text: What IDE is that?  I will be starting JS soon and I like the feature of how your console.log() function updates the result as you enter code.

topLevelComment.author: warth666
topLevelComment.text: It's a bit to complicated approach for me. Can we just create one array from 1 to 30 and play let's say 13:35 -> It's tweny five to two pm? I think it's more straightforward. What do you think?

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: Yeah, this could probably have been accomplished using a single array and changing up the logic to figure out which index to use.  See if you can implement it a better way and paste it here!

topLevelComment.author: keelaboosa
topLevelComment.text: I'd like to see how you attach the speech part to this.  Nice video!

replies.author: Sandip Nirmal
freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: If you are familiar with node, you can just install an npm package called 'say' and pass it a string to have it read using text-to-speech.  https://www.npmjs.com/package/say
